titleStmt.title: Lausanne, Lausanne Collection, no call number

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

summary.p: Single parchment folio; Shelfmark: no call number; Qurʾānic Text: Q 5:19-28; Lines per page: 13; Dimensions: 337 x 237 mm; Script style: kūfī, variation of the type D.Va; Estimated date of production: 750-850.
Originally, the Lausanne fragment and four other fragments (HC.MS.03168 and HC.MS.03113 from Doha; sxm/ag. 2529 from Tbilisi and AL-15 from Washington) probably belong to the same codex.

support.p: Recto is flesh side, verso is hair side.

Text division: There are single, fifth and tenth verse separators. The single verse separators are small golden rosettes. Verse separators for a cluster of five verses (preserved on fol. 1v line 2) are marked by the letter hāʾ painted in gold colour, the letter hāʾ representing the number 5 in the abjad counting system. Interestingly, the taḫmīs marker has been placed after the word ġālibūna in 5:23. This variant in the verse counting is attested only in the Baṣran tradition of verse separation (see (Spitaler 1935: PN 36). The Baṣran tradition also counts this verse as the 25th, which would explain the taḫmīs marking. There must have been a tenth verse separator on the verso side at the beginning of line 12, which was probably deliberately damaged. The illumination was placed after the 30th verse according to the Baṣran tradition, but after the 27th according to the Kufan. On the basis of observations made only on one surviving folio, it is difficult to argue that the codex followed the Baṣran tradition of the verse counting.

summary.p: The script of this Qurʾān fragment represents the kūfī script style D being close to the D.Va group with elements of D.I/D.II as these subgroups are very similar (Déroche 1983: PN 112-116), (Déroche 1992: PN 44-45). The letter ʾalif in the independent form has a long lower return with an upward curve. The letter ǧīm in the medial form lies on the base line so that the letter before it is placed a little bit higher. In the final or independent position ǧīm has a tail that curves back to the head of the letter close to the line, similar to the D.I/D.II group. The letter ṭāʾ in the final or independent position is similar to those in the D.Va group. ʿAyn initially resembles the D.Va group. In middle position, the letter shows a vertical right hand antenna which remains vertical in final position as well. Qāf in its final or independent form shows a U-shaped tail that goes backwards as in D.II group. The letter mīm in middle and final position is closer to D.II and D.III group. In both positions the letter lies rather flat on the line, in final position it has a short flat tail. Nūn in final and independent position has a long body and the head is shorter than in D.I, being closer to D.III. Hāʾ in the medial position is placed on the base line, the two eyes are mostly defined. The shape of the letter, which resembles a drop is close to the D.Va group. The lām-ʾalif ligature also resembles D.Va and D.I group, but the lām is much thinner than ʾalif and curves towards it.
Unlike Déroche, we use the term kūfī for pragmatic reasons - a term which is attested only after the 10th century.

Diacritics: Diacritica of the script are marked by oblique dashes in the same dark brown ink as the main text, mostly, the letters bāʾ and nūn in final or independent position are marked. Vocalisation is indicated by red and green dots. Some lines show mašq, horizontal stretching of the letters, a technique used to achieve a regular arrangement of letters within a line.
